case_name: Ahmedabad Manufacturing Calico Printing Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Twelve Writ Petitions filed by diverse textile mills and other factories of Ahmedabad challenging the imposition of the Education Cess pursuant to the Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: These are twelve Writ Petitions by diverse textile mills and other factories of Ahmedabad challenging the imposition of the Education Cess pursuant to the Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962.

facts.text: Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962 became law on October 9, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On October 9, 1962, the Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962 became law. It is an Act to provide for the creation of a fund to promote education in the State of Gujarat.

facts.text: The Act applies to the City of Ahmedabad as constituted under the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Act applies to the City of Ahmedabad as constituted under the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act, 1949. Under the Cess Act education cess is levied on lands and buildings which have the meanings given to them under the relevant Local Authority Law here the Corporation Act.

facts.text: Education cess levied on lands and buildings in urban areas as a tax.

anchor.surface_text: a tax on lands and buildings in urban areas. Village Site means the site of a village, town or city determined under s. 126 of the relevant Code which in this case is the Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879 and urban area means an area which is for the time being included in the limits of a city, municipal borough, etc.

facts.text: Under s. 5, surcharge levied at 20 paise on every rupee of land revenue on lands assessed or held for agriculture but not used for agriculture.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 5, a surcharge is levied at the rate of 20 paise on every rupee of every sum assessed as land revenue on all lands  except lands included within a village. site and number assessed to land revenue  which are assessed or held for the purpose of agriculture and number used for any purpose unconnected with agriculture.

facts.text: Under s. 12, tax on lands and buildings in urban areas at 3% of annual letting value for trade, commerce, industry, etc., raised to 4.5% from October 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 12, a tax on lands and buildings situated in urban area is levied at varying rates depending on the use to which the lands and buildings are put. In every case, the tax is a percentage of the annual letting value which means the ratable value or annual letting value or gross annual letting value of lands and buildings determined in accordance with the relevant local authority law which as stated earlier is the Corporation Act.

facts.text: Annual letting value for textile mills determined on flat rate of Rs. 6-10as. per 100 sq. foot processing portion and Rs. 5-4as. non-processing portion.

anchor.surface_text: According to the assessment book, the annual letting value for the purpose of levying property tax on textile mills, factories, buildings of universities, etc., is made on the basis of a flat rate of a monthly rental of Rs. 6-10as. for the processing portion and Rs. 5-4as. for the number-processing portion, per 100 sq. foot of the floor area of such property situated in the urban area.

facts.text: In Writ Petitions Nos. 133, 156-157, 159-171, 178-209, 210 and 234 of 1966 decided on February 21, 1967 by Mitter J, floor area method for annual letting value held bad and inclusion of plant and machinery illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The details of the working of the system are fully described by our brother Mitter, in his judgment in Writ Petitions Nos. 133, 156-157, 159-171, 178 206-209, 210 and 234 of 1966 decided on Feb- ruary 21, 1967, where these mills and factories have successfully challenged the assessment book.

facts.text: Properties in Ahmedabad in three zones: inner zone no land revenue, middle zone diverted agricultural lands bear non-agricultural assessment and municipal tax, outer zone pure agricultural lands bear land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The properties in Ahmedabad are in three zones which may be described as demarcated by three concentric circles. In the inner zone are situated properties which do number bear land revenue and numbersurcharge is therefore payable in respect of lands and buildings.

facts.text: Textile mills of the petitioners situated in the middle zone within municipal limits of Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: The textile mills of the petitioners are situated in the middle zone within the municipal limits of Ahmedabad and the main companylaint in these cases is that by reason of their situation, these mills have to pay both the surcharge as well as the tax whereas the owners of property in the other two zones bear either a surcharge on the land revenue or a tax on the annual letting value.

facts.text: Petitioners complain that mills in middle zone pay both surcharge and tax unlike other zones.

anchor.surface_text: and the main companylaint in these cases is that by reason of their situation, these mills have to pay both the surcharge as well as the tax whereas the owners of property in the other two zones bear either a surcharge on the land revenue or a tax on the annual letting value.

facts.text: Preparation of assessment book struck down by this Court, so annual letting value not presently available, conceded by State of Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, numberdoubt that the annual letting value or ratable value is number presently available since the decision of this Court has struck down the assessment book itself. This is companyceded on behalf of the State of Gujarat.

facts.text: Court holds that s.12 does not fail despite assessment book issues.

anchor.surface_text: The question is, does this make s. 12 -to fail also? In our judgment it does number. Section 12 lays down that the tax on lands and buildings situated in urban areas shall be companylected at the rate of 3 of the annual letting value  number 4.5  where a building or land is used for the purpose of trade, companymerce, industry, profession or business.

facts.text: Inner zone properties exempted from land revenue under s.128 Bombay Land Revenue Code.

anchor.surface_text: Properties in this zone were exempted from the payment of land revenue under S. 128 of the Bombay Land Revenue Code in Ahmedabad in companymon with other towns and cities in which there had been formerly a city survey.

facts.text: Middle zone lands originally agricultural diverted to non-agricultural use, bear non-agricultural assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In the middle zone are situated lands which though originally agricultural lands have been diverted to number-agricultural use and the lands and buildings therefore bear both municipal tax and number-agricultural assess- ment.

facts.text: Petitioners argue discrimination between middle zone and inner zone properties.

anchor.surface_text: The second argument that there is discrimination between properties in the middle zone and the inner zone may number be companysidered.

facts.text: Flat rate for annual letting value and inclusion of plant and machinery objected by petitioners, corrected by Mitter J decision.

anchor.surface_text: The first and second are  a  that flat rate is applied in calculating the annual letting value and  b  that plant and machinery are included in lands and buildings. This has been companyrected by the decision of our brother Mitter.

facts.text: Double imposition in middle zone not offensive to Art.14 unless shown to fall more heavily.

anchor.surface_text: A double imposition by itself is number offensive to Art. 14 of the Constitution unless it can be shown that the double tax in one zone as companypared with the single tax in the other zones falls more heavily than the single tax.

facts.text: Cess Act does not provide own procedure for assessment, uses existing taxes, no violation of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: Finally there is the argument that the Cess Act, in number pro- viding its own procedure of assessment and in number giving the tax-payers an opportunity for putting forward their objections by way of representation, appeal or otherwise, before the tax is finally fixed, offends the principles of natural justice.

facts.text: Court declines to issue writ in these petitions.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we decline to issue a writ in these petitions.

facts.text: Writ Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 12 and 17 to 21 of 1967, and 239, 240, 244 and 246 to 249 of 1966. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Hidayatullah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hidayatullah, J. These are twelve Writ Petitions by diverse textile mills and other factories of Ahmedabad challenging the imposition of the Education Cess pursuant to the Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962.

facts.text: Reference to petition by Ahmedabad Manufacturing Calico Printing Co. Ltd., Writ Petition No. 12 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: As the contents of all petitions are the same, it will be sufficient if we refer to the petition filed by the Ahmedabad Manufacturing Calico Printing Co. Ltd.  Writ Petition No. 12 of 1967 .

ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 12 and 17 to 21 of 1967, and 239, 240, 244 and 246 to 249 of 1966. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.
These are twelve Writ Petitions by diverse textile mills and other factories of Ahmedabad challenging the imposition of the Education Cess pursuant to the Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962.

issues.text: Whether Section 12 of the Gujarat Education Cess Act fails because the assessment book has been struck down and no annual letting value is presently available?

anchor.surface_text: The question is, does this make s. 12 -to fail also? In our judgment it does not. Section 12 lays down that the tax on lands and buildings situated in urban areas shall be collected at the rate of 3% of the annual letting value (now 4.5%) where a building or land is used for the purpose of trade, commerce, industry, profession or business.

issues.text: Whether the double imposition of both surcharge and tax on properties in the middle zone as compared to single imposition in inner and outer zones violates Article 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: the main complaint in these cases is that by reason of their situation, these mills have to pay both the surcharge as well as the tax whereas the owners of property in the other two zones bear either a surcharge on the land revenue or a tax on the annual letting value.

issues.text: Whether the Gujarat Education Cess Act offends principles of natural justice by not providing its own procedure of assessment and opportunity for objections?

anchor.surface_text: Finally there is the argument that the Cess Act, in not pro- viding its own procedure of assessment and in not giving the tax-payers an opportunity for putting forward their objections by way of representation, appeal or otherwise, before the tax is finally fixed, offends the principles of natural justice.

issues.text: Whether the levy of education cess under the Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962 violates fundamental rights under Article 32?

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 12 and 17 to 21 of 1967, and 239, 240, 244 and 246 to 249 of 1966. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights. ... These are twelve Writ Petitions by diverse textile mills and other factories of Ahmedabad challenging the imposition of the Education Cess pursuant to the Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962.

arguments.claim: Preparation of assessment book struck down makes tax under s.12 no longer leviable and s.12 inoperative, causing entire Cess Act to fail

anchor.surface_text: It is also contended that the preparation of the assessment book having been struck down by this Court in the case cited earlier by us, the tax under s. 12 is no longer leviable and s. 12 having become inoperative, the Cess Act must fall as a whole.

anchor.surface_text: The textile mills of the petitioners are situated in the middle zone within the municipal limits of Ahmedabad and the main complaint in these cases is that by reason of their situation, these mills have to pay both the surcharge as well as the tax whereas the owners of property in the other two zones bear either a surcharge on the land revenue or a tax on the annual letting value.

arguments.court_reasoning: Double imposition not offensive to Art.14 unless falls more heavily; zones result from different historical laws and uses; equitable adjustment of rates considering benefits

arguments.claim: Cess Act offends natural justice by not providing own assessment procedure or opportunity for objections, representations or appeals

anchor.surface_text: Finally there is the argument that the Cess Act, in not providing its own procedure of assessment and in not giving the tax-payers an opportunity for putting forward their objections by way of representation, appeal or otherwise, before the tax is finally fixed, offends the principles of natural justice.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ts own procedure of assessment and in number giving the tax-payers an opportunity for putting forward their objections by way of representation, appea

arguments.court_reasoning: Cess is percentage addition to existing taxes assessed under other acts with full procedures for objections and appeals; no independent assessment needed; common practice for cesses by incorporation and reference valid

arguments.claim: Annual letting value or ratable value not presently available due to struck down assessment book

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, no doubt that the annual letting value or ratable value is not presently available since the decision of this Court has struck down the assessment book itself.

arguments.claim: Section 12 valid despite struck down assessment book as it applies to annual letting value determined under municipal corporation act including future revisions

anchor.surface_text: The question is, does this make s. 12 to fail also? In our judgment it does not. Section 12 lays down that the tax on lands and buildings situated in urban areas shall be collected at the rate of 3% of the annual letting value (now 4.5%) where a building or land is used for the purpose of trade, commerce, industry, profession or business.

arguments.claim: No discrimination under Art.14 in middle zone double levy as zones arise from different laws, tax bases differ, and rates adjusted equitably considering situation and education benefits

anchor.surface_text: A double imposition by itself is not offensive to Art. 14 of the Constitution unless it can be shown that the double tax in one zone as compared with the single tax in the other zones falls more heavily than the single tax.

arguments.claim: Cess Act complies with natural justice as it incorporates procedures from base taxing acts which provide objections and appeals

anchor.surface_text: This argument is not correct. The cess is nothing more than an addition to existing taxes. As it is a percentage of another tax, the determination of the cess is not by an independent assessment.

holdings.text: Section 12 of the Gujarat Education Cess Act does not fail merely because the assessment book has been struck down and annual letting value is not presently available; it applies to the annual letting value as determined under the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act, including future revisions.

anchor.surface_text: The question is, does this make s. 12 -to fail also? In our judgment it does number. Section 12 lays down that the tax on lands and buildings situated in urban areas shall be companylected at the rate of 3 of the annual letting value  number 4.5  where a building or land is used for the purpose of trade, companymerce, industry, profession or business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The section prescribes a tax rate on annual letting value determined under municipal law; striking down current book requires revision but does not invalidate the section, which remains applicable to new valuations.

holdings.text: There is no discrimination under Article 14 due to double imposition of surcharge and tax in the middle zone compared to single impositions in inner and outer zones.

anchor.surface_text: A double imposition by itself is number offensive to Art. 14 of the Constitution unless it can be shown that the double tax in one zone as companypared with the single tax in the other zones falls more heavily than the single tax. This is number attempted to be established except on the ground of flat rate above mentioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Zones arise from historical laws and different tax bases; double tax not violative unless proven heavier burden; rates adjusted equitably considering benefits from education and municipal services; no evidence of undue burden shown.

holdings.text: The Gujarat Education Cess Act does not offend principles of natural justice by not providing its own assessment procedure or opportunities for objections.

anchor.surface_text: This argument is number companyrect. The cess is numberhing more than an addition to existing taxes. As it is a percentage of another tax, the determination of the cess is number by an independent assessment. It is an arithmetical calculation based on the result of assessment under other Act or Acts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cess is a percentage addition to taxes assessed under other laws that already provide objections and appeals; no independent assessment required; common legislative practice of incorporation by reference is valid and constitutional.

holdings.text: The levy of education cess under the Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962 does not violate fundamental rights; writ petitions dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we decline to issue a writ in these petitions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges to validity rejected on merits; no violations of Articles 14, 32 or natural justice found.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: In the result we decline to issue a writ in these petitions.

outcome.relief_summary: Court declines to issue writ; writ petitions challenging the Gujarat Education Cess Act dismissed
